theText: Prime MinThe following answers to questions were circulated: Taxation: Family Payments (Question No. 359) Ms Jackson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 15 May 2002: (1) How many families and individuals in the electoral division of Hasluck have received a (a) Family Tax Benefit debt notice and (b) Child Care Benefit debt notice. (2) How many child care centres in the electoral division of Hasluck have received a debt notice arising from the old Child Care Assistance Scheme. (3) What steps is the Government taking to guarantee that families will not be penalised by the current income self assessment regime where their incomes fluctuate through no fault of their own, because they carry out varying amounts of overtime in their employment, or their employment is commission based, or where one of the partners returns to the workforce after raising children. (4) Is the Minister aware that on pages 3 and 4 of the Estimating your Income booklet produced by the Family Assistance Office, the suggestions for estimating income for the year ahead include (a) knowing whether the recipient or his or her partner will receive termination or insurance payments or (b) predicting whether a partner will recommence work; if so, should individuals be expected to know whether they will lose their jobs, have to make an insurance claim or take up new employment in the forthcoming year. lowing answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) (a) As at 24 May 2002, 4,688 customers in the electoral division of Hasluck have received notification that they incurred a Family Tax Benefit debt as a result of the income reconciliation process. (b) As at 24 May 2002, 931 customers in the electoral division of Hasluck have received notification that they incurred a Child Care Benefit debt as a result of the income reconciliation process. Note: only customers who incurred a debt over $1,000 would have a recoverable debt. (2) The number of child care centres in the electoral division of Hasluck that have received a debt notice arising from the old Child Care Assistance Scheme is 23. (3) The Family Assistance Office actively helps families to avoid or minimise family assistance overpayments resulting from underestimates of income through a range of communications with customers explaining the income estimation process and encouraging customers to keep their estimates up-to-date. Families are encouraged to estimate at the top of the range of their possible income for the year and can change their estimate as often as they wish during the year. The reconciliation process ensures that families receive their correct entitlement based on their actual taxable income. Families also have the option of claiming their family assistance as a lump sum after the end of the financial year when their taxable income has been assessed and thereby avoid any chance of overpayment. (4) The Estimating your Income booklet is provided to assist customers in providing an accurate estimate of their income for the coming financial year. This minimises the possibility of families incurring an FTB debt. Pages 3-4 of the booklet list “some questions you might have to think about when working out your estimated family income”. This list includes: commencing work, termination payments, child support and compensation or insurance payments. Customers can use this checklist when providing their initial income estimate and/or when updating their estimate. The provision of the checklist does not imply that families must be able to anticipate all changes to their income in advance. On the contrary, the booklet emphasises (on page 8) that if customers think the estimate they gave is wrong or might have changed, they should tell the Family Assistance Office as soon as possible, and that they can change their estimate as often as they need to.

(2) How many phone calls are received by the Family Assistance Office each week. (3) How many phone operators are available to answer calls to the Family Assistance Office on 13 6150. (4) What is the longest period callers to the Family Assistance Office on the 13 61 50 number will have to wait to have their calls answered. (5) In introducing a system where families and individuals receiving Family Tax Benefit or Child Care Benefit have to report any changes in their family income to the Family Assistance Office, was it envisaged that these people would have their calls answered promptly. (6) Is the Minister aware (a) that many Australians work in several part time or casual jobs without set hours or incomes each fortnight and must report changed circumstances regularly to the Family Assistance Office and (b) of the frustration many Australians experience in trying to call the 13 61 50 phone number to report their changed circumstances. (7) Is the Minister also aware that it was not possible to get through to the 13 61 50 phone number on 10 and 11 June 2002, and that on phoning the number, there was an engaged signal only. lowing answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) (a) Centrelink records show that 1,940,000 customers successfully claimed Family Tax Benefit PartA and 1,360,000 customers successfully claimed Family Tax Benefit PartB as fortnightly payments in 2000-2001. (b) There were 592,000 families and individuals who received Child Care Benefit as a fee reduction during the 2000-2001 financial year. (2) During a three week period in June 2002, the Family Assistance Office averaged 144,106 successful calls per week. (3) For the month of June there were 1353 operators available in the FAO. (4) Centrelink Call aims to minimise the average wait time. For the month of June the Average Speed of Answer (ASA) was 297 seconds. The longest delay experienced by a customer in the three week period ending 21 June 2002 was 1700 seconds. (5) The Family Assistance Office was designed to give customers a choice in both delivery method and contact points. Customers can contact over the phone, via the Internet or in person at any Centrelink Office, Medicare Office or ATOaccess sites. Centrelink anticipates workload demand and allocates staff to meet expected demand, however, on occasions demand exceeds expectation. (6) (a) Customers who choose to receive their Family Tax Benefit by fortnightly instalments through Centrelink need to advise an estimate of income for the whole financial year. Families can earn up to $30,806 before it will affect Family Tax Benefit part A. PartB is affected by the income of the secondary income earner. It is not a requirement to advise the Family Assistance Office of fortnightly earnings. (b) In the twelve months to 30 August 2002 there were 8,145,908 successful calls to the FAO with an average speed of answer (ASA) of 115 seconds. (7) The 10th of June was a Public Holiday, in all States and Territories except for Western Australia, therefore Centrelink was closed in all sites except for Western Australia. On 10 June 2002, 3652 calls were answered in the FAO, with an Average Speed of Answer of 265 seconds. On 11 June 2002, 31,864 calls were answered in the FAO with an Average Speed of Answer of 328 seconds.

theText: The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the folEmployment: Mature Age Workers (Question No. 627) Ms Plibersek asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 26 June 2002: (1) What substantive measures is the Minister taking to facilitate the re-entry into the workforce of those mature age workers who have had career breaks or who find themselves between jobs and unable to regain a foothold in the employment market. (2) How many older Australian workers have re-entered the workforce as a result of the measures. lowing answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) Several new measures were announced under the “Australians Working Together” package. The Government will spend $146 million over four years to help working-age people from 50 years to Age Pension age who receive income support payments to improve their job prospects this includes extra Centrelink services and more places in services such as rehabilitation and disability employment services, English as a second language courses, literacy and numeracy training and other education and training opportunities. From September 2002, people on Mature Age Allowance, Widow Allowance and Partner Allowance – who, because they are not activity tested, currently receive little employment assistance will be invited to attend voluntary interviews with a Centrelink Personal Adviser. Centrelink Personal Advisers will help identify people’s needs and the obstacles they may face and refer them to appropriate services. From July 2003, a simpler income support structure will be introduced for older working-age people, with no new entrants to the non-activity tested Mature Age Allowance and Partner Allowance. People over 50 will claim Newstart Allowance instead, but with much more flexible requirements than currently apply to Newstart Allowance, together with individually focussed support. All new Widow Allowees will have an annual interview with a Centrelink Personal Adviser to help them plan for the future. They will also be able to access Personal Advisers on a more regular basis if they wish. In addition, mature age people will be able to access: Job Search Training places without having to wait until they have been unemployed for three months (commenced 1 July 2002); Training Credits of up to $800 and personal training that covers resumé development, written references and updating job seekers’ skills, for people participating in Work for the Dole or community work monitored by Community Work Coordinators (commenced 1 July 2002); Training Accounts of up to $800 for people participating in Job Search Training and Intensive Assistance (commenced 1 July 2002); the new Transition to Work Programme, which helps people return to paid work after long absences (commenced 1 July 2002); specialist information for people who are facing retrenchment or who have been retrenched; information on how best to establish a small business; Intensive Assistance assessments resulting in referrals to complementary programmes; a Working Credit under which people of working age on income support may be able to keep some or all of their payment when they first start work or have intermittent work; and the new Personal Support Programme, which assists people with severe or multiple obstacles to getting a job (commenced 1 July 2002). (2) The majority of these measures have yet to commence, or have only recently commenced, and so I am unable to answer this question.

The values shown are 12-month running means. (2) The long-term trends show an improvement in both temperature and rainfall forecasting. The percentage of accurate rainfall forecasts has increased from about 70% to 75%. The temperature statistics are presented in terms of significant errors and mean absolute errors. There is a long-term improvement in both the maximum and minimum temperature forecast performance as well as a substantial reduction in the number of large errors in temperature forecasts, particularly for maximum temperature. The downward trend over time in the S1 skill scores suggests that the operational predictions from the Australian region analysis and prediction system have contributed to the general improvement in forecasting of weather elements. Improvements in forecast performance can be explained by a number of factors including: (a) Improved skill of numerical weather prediction (NWP) models (cf. The S1 skill scores); (b) Introduction and updating of automated guidance to forecasters based on algorithms and NWP output; (c) Introduction of strategically-located automatic weather stations to provide an improved observations network; (d) Improved observing systems (particularly weather watch radar and radiosondes); (e) Improved satellite data; (f) Continuing research leading to improved understanding of the science of meteorology and the development of automated guidance tools, along with more detailed case studies allowing better understanding of specific events; (g) Computerised systems allowing for more effective and timely presentation of data to forecasters; and (h) Improvements in training, particularly in ongoing training for operational forecasters. (3) While it is reasonable to look at trends in accuracy at a particular location, care must be exercised in comparing accuracy between locations. This is because there are significant differences in the variability in weather elements from one part of Australia to the next. In cities where the weather is naturally more variable, the forecasting of temperatures and rainfall will be more difficult. For example, it is easier to forecast the maximum temperature at, say, Darwin where the maximum temperature might be consistently around 31 to 33 degrees for most of the year, than in Canberra where there is a significant variation in maximum temperature from day to day. Establishing measures of forecasting skill that are independent of location is a problem that has yet to be effectively solved. It is probably true to say that every location has its own forecasting challenges and while temperature forecasts are problematic at one location, forecasting rainfall or wind or thunderstorms might be a particular problem at another. Veterans’ Affairs: Program Funding (Question No. 759) Ms Burke asked the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: (1) Does the Minister administer any Commonwealth funded programs for which community organisations or businesses can apply for funding. (2) If so, what are these programs. (3) Does the Minister’s Department advertise these funding opportunities. (4) In the electoral divisions of (a) Chisholm, (b) Aston, (c) Deakin, (d) Latrobe and (e) Casey in (i) 1996-97, (ii) 1997-98, (iii) 1998-99, (iv) 1999-2000, (v) 2000-2001 and (vi) 2001-2002, for each of the programs listed in part (2), (A) what was the name and postal address of each organisation that sought funding from the Commonwealth, (B) what was the purpose of the funding sought in each case and (C) for successful applications, what was the level of funding provided. Mrs Vale-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) Yes (2) There are 4 funding programs that the Department of Veterans’ Affairs administers. They are: Building Excellence in Support and Training (BEST) program – The aim of this program is to provide support and resources to ex-service organisation practitioners for pension and welfare work to assist veterans and widow(er)s. Veteran and Community Grants– These grants aim to maintain and improve the independence and quality of life of members of the veteran community. The grants provide funding for projects which promote healthier lifestyles and enhance health, support carers, reduce social isolation and assist veterans and war widow(er)s to remain in their own homes as long as possible. Projects may meet the needs of others in the community if there is sufficient capacity. Saluting Their Service– Saluting Their Service is the Federal Government’s commemorations program. It aims to highlight the sacrifice and service of Australia’s servicemen and women in wars, conflicts and peacekeeping operations since Federation and to promote appreciation and understanding of the role that those who have served have played in shaping the nation. The program is designed to preserve our heritage from wars and conflicts and encourage community participation in commemorative events. It aims to involve people throughout the nation in a wide range of activities and projects. Modest grants up to $4,000 for projects, including events and activities that meet the aims and objectives of Saluting Their Service, may be provided. Funding assistance may be provided for the restoration, preservation and upgrading of community war memorials or, where no memorial exists in the town or suburb, the construction of a new memorial. Funding may also be provided for the restoration, preservation and interpretation of Australian wartime memorabilia for public display, commemorative plaques and honour boards for public display, commemoration of significant anniversaries of battles and other military operations and school initiatives, eg research projects involving local veterans. Grants-in-Aid– The aim of this program is to assist national ex-service organisations with their administration costs in recognition of the services that they provide to the ex-service community. (3) Advertising of the 4 funding programs that the Department of Veterans’ Affairs administers is outlined below: Building Excellence in Support and Training (BEST) Program– The BEST program is not advertised in the commercial media. However, the BEST program is promoted by: annual forums held by State Deputy Commissioners with various peak ex-service organisation representatives to address BEST funding for the coming financial year. From these forums, peak ex-service organisation representatives advise their members of funding arrangements; the Training Information Program (TIP). Information on the BEST program is incorporated into some TIP training sessions held in the States; the Department of Veterans’ Affairs website. All details, including the application form, guidelines and contact details as well as an information sheet, are on the Department of Veterans’ Affairs website; and letter mail out advising of forthcoming BEST application periods. The mail out is circulated to existing grantees notifying them of forthcoming BEST funding. Veteran and Community Grants– The Veteran& Community Grants are not advertised in the commercial media. However, Veteran& Community Grants are promoted by: the Department of Veterans’ Affairs State Office staff, Veterans’ Affairs Network (VAN) Office Staff and Community Advisers. Information about Veteran& Community Grants are disseminated at this level through local visits, forums (such as ex-service organisation grant workshops), mail outs and newsletter articles directed at ex-service and targeted community organisations; the Grantslink website, an all of government website which has a direct link to the Veteran& Community Grants site on the Department of Veterans’ Affairs website; and the Department of Veterans’ Affairs website. All details, including the application form, guidelines and contact details as well as an information sheet, are on the Department of Veterans’ Affairs website. Saluting Their Service– Saluting Their Service is not advertised in the general commercial media. However, Saluting Their Service is promoted by: the Department of Veterans’ Affairs disseminating information to community and ex-service organisations, local government authorities and other bodies such as museums and schools; Federal Members of Parliament disseminating information in their electorates, directly to organisations and through media releases and electoral newsletters; the Grantslink website, an all of government website which has a direct link to the Saluting Their Service site on the Department of Veterans’ Affairs website; the Department of Veterans’ Affairs website. All details, including the application form, guidelines and contact details as well as an information sheet, are on the Department of Veterans’ Affairs website; and on occasions, paid advertisements in industry specific publications, for example local government authority journals and educational publications. Grants-in-Aid– No advertising is undertaken with the Grants-in-Aid program but the application form is available on the Department of Veterans’ Affairs website. Trade: Chrysotile Asbestos (Question No. 885) Ms George asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, upon notice on, 29 August 2002: What steps are being undertaken by the Government to implement the proposed ban on the use and importation of chrysotile asbestos? The May 2001 meeting of the Workplace Relations Ministers’ Council (WRMC) agreed to the imposition of a ban on the import and use of chrysotile asbestos no later than 31 December 2003. WRMC also asked the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (NOHSC) to undertake essential consultation to facilitate imposing bans on all other forms of asbestos. Since that time the following steps have been taken on a national basis to prohibit the use and importation of chrysotile asbestos: At the WRMC meeting in September 2001, Ministers endorsed proposed amendments to Schedule2 (Substances prohibited for specific uses) of the NOHSC National Model Regulations for the Control of Workplace Hazardous Substances (Model Regulations), to prohibit the use of chrysotile, crocidolite and amosite asbestos. This meeting also endorsed implementation arrangements to effect the ban on chrysotile asbestos, including developing a nationally consistent approach to exemptions and a proposal to develop recommendations for prohibiting all other forms of asbestos. Prohibition on the import of asbestos and any exemptions is to be effected through regulations to be made under the Customs Act 1901 following completion of public consultation by NOHSC. The World Trade Organisation was duly notified in September 2001 of Australia’s intention to prohibit chrysotile asbestos. Consistent with WRMC’s approval NOHSC declared the amendments to the Model Regulations on 17 October 2001 listing the uses prohibited. The States and Territories will make appropriate regulations or legislate to bring the prohibition on the use of chrysotile and other forms of asbestos into effect. Following the implementation of the prohibition, Australian Design Rules are to be revised in 2004 prohibiting the use of asbestos in brake linings in motor vehicles. In May 2002 NOHSC reported to WRMC that all jurisdictions were on track to implement the prohibition from 31 December 2003. WRMC also agreed to nationally consistent arrangements for exemptions to the prohibition through the development of a National List of Exemptions. In June 2002, NOHSC released a public consultation discussion paper on the proposed National List of Exemptions. Comments on the discussion paper closed on 13 September 2002. In the same month NOHSC also initiated a review of the exposure standard for chrysotile asbestos. NOHSC is to report to WRMC in November 2002 on further progress towards implementation of the prohibition, including all forms of asbestos, arising from its public consultations and consideration of proposed exemption arrangements. The Government’s responsibilities in relation to the prohibition of the use of chrysotile include Commonwealth employment and the shipping industry. In relation to Commonwealth employment: On 26 September 2001, the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Commission (the Commission) endorsed that the prohibition of use of chrysotile and other forms of asbestos is to be as consistent as possible with the NOHSC model regulations which prohibit the use of chrysotile and other forms of asbestos. China: Blood Collection Agencies (Question No. 913) Mr Danby asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 16 May 2002: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the practice of government affiliated blood collection agencies in China pooling blood to extract plasma and then returning the pooled blood to donors to prevent anaemia. (2) Is he able to say whether this practice has led to infection of blood donor supplies by individuals with HIV and AIDS. (3) Is he able to say whether, despite a recent Chinese central government crackdown, local officials persist in selling tainted blood. (4) Are Australian authorities aware that Henan province was the epicentre of this blood selling business and in some villages over 60% of residents are now HIV positive; if so, is his Department able to confirm whether in that province, in a majority of families, a majority of adults have died and only youth or elderly remain. (5) Is it expected that at the forthcoming 16th Party Congress of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), Li Chang Chun, the Henan CCP Chief and protégé of Premier Jiang Zemin, will be elevated as Vice Premier. (6) Has the Australian Government offered to provide Australian public education programs on the prevention of the spread of HIV and AIDS to national and regional governments in China. (7) What steps, if any, has the Australian Government taken to warn Australian tourists to China of the danger of accessing local blood supplies in the event of being involved in accidents. (1) and (2) The Government is aware of credible reports that in a number of Chinese provinces, predominantly in central China, there has been a practice of people selling their blood and plasma to commercial blood processing companies. The practice of pooling the blood, separating the plasma and then re-injecting red blood cells back into donors has led to the rapid spread of HIV in these areas. (3) In 1998 China passed a blood donation law prohibiting commercial blood donations and stipulating that all blood collected for medical transfusions should be from voluntary donations. The Government is aware of reports that some blood-collecting companies continue to operate illegally, particularly in remote, impoverished areas where authorities find it harder to prevent the practice. (4) The Government is aware that the practice of commercial blood collection existed in Henan Province, though the practice was prevalent in a number of central Chinese provinces in the 1990s. Figures vary on the current extent of HIV infection in Henan province; estimates range from the Chinese Ministry of Health’s figure of 150,000 to above 1 million HIV-infected people. The UN theme group on HIV/AIDS in China quotes reports from local residents that in some villages in the province more than 80% of adults are HIV positive. (5) The Government cannot speculate on this. (6) Australia is funding projects to combat the spread of HIV/AIDS in nine provinces in China. All projects include the provision of health education programs to improve knowledge of HIV/AIDS prevention and control among the general population and special programs for high-risk groups. Several of these projects also include components supporting the national government’s agenda for the implementation of safe blood supply and reducing risk of transfusing infected blood. (7) The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade reviewed the travel advice for China at the end of September 2002. It advises that the availability of reliable medical care in China is limited, particularly outside of major cities. Travellers are strongly advised to have the appropriate health insurance in the event they need to reach a reliable medical centre.
